1524997617_1CcoRvm8AhLxYLtYoXwwzobh74Kzc.body:
But what differs AI and our minds? We know very little about dreams, for example. 

If you ask yourself: "how my body saves energy due sleeping" you, maybe, would answer: "because it moves less"
If you would dig deeper into problem, you would find out, what dreams - is a very complicated visualisation process with procedure (?) story-generation, running similar process on computer will cost a lot of energy, so what the benefit of dreams really?

Here is two possible explanations:
- our mind very efficient (millions times more, then a traditional PC)
- theory of fundamental information was right, so we can access world of information via our brains to gather images of what we see in dreams

So, maybe, AI wouldn't be so good as we imagine, if they have missing parts

> [shitchell](#comment_28_1LybGoL99LBuYE8ZtwgJC8dxkii3UmYKpo): Interesting example that you picked. Hebbian learning is postulated as a model used by our brains and used in neural networks for machine learning. We receive a bunch of input and we find patterns. In machine learning, a problem can arise, however, that looks like so: [...]
I never thought about it, interesting version. It makes sense if you remember how your memory is restructured during sleep time, but it looks... simplified? 

Dreams are non-linear and unpredictable at the same time, you can get same dream during whole week, so instead of unlearning, you will get fragments with a lot of weight. And the most rediculous, what these fragments aren't based on your real experience, so they affect on the way you think separately of input. 

Here is a bigger question. Our brain is self-regulated network, so it must have learning algorythm from the start, newborn knows how to learn, even if he grew up from single cell. I'm asking myself about it for long and at this moment I couldn't find answer, how neural network grows in our head, because if humanity finds way to generate same self-learning network, it would be a key to real AI. 
If nature can grow this network from almost nothing (10^7bit of information in DNA isn't big amount of data and DNA stores a lot of another infomation), it is quite impressive.
